channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tycoon’s Trials Rivet Serbia, Land of Graft
item.description: The Serbian government hailed the arrest of Miroslav Miskovic as part of a crackdown on corruption to aid the country’s bid to join the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Miroslav Miskovic in 2010. The businessman is facing charges of fraud and tax evasion.

item.title: Israeli Decree on West Bank Settlements Will Harm Peace Talks, Palestinians Say
item.description: The decision involving the settlements highlighted the fragility of the Washington-brokered effort to resume peace negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Trial Set for Brotherhood Officials in Deaths at Anti-Morsi Riots
item.description: Pending prosecutions for three officials are a new blow to the Muslim Brotherhood, which emerged as Egypt’s strongest political movement in 2011 but whose power has dissipated.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Supporters of Mohamed Morsi in Giza, Egypt, on Sunday. The Muslim Brotherhood’s power has dissipated in recent weeks.

item.title: In a West Bank Culture of Conflict, Boys Wield the Weapon at Hand
item.description: For Palestinian young men and boys, throwing stones at Israeli soldiers and settlers is a rite of passage.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: The arrest of Ahmad Abu Hashem and his son Muhammad on July 8 was almost routine for a family in which few months have passed recently without at least one member behind bars. Mr. Abu Hashem, an activist in Beit Ommar, and all six of his sons have served time for throwing stones at Israeli soldiers and settlers. Source: Abu Hashem family and Israel Defense Forces

item.title: Mom Wants You Married? So Does the State
item.description: In South Korea, the government is playing a bigger role in matchmaking amid plunging birthrates and changing expectations over matrimony.
item.dc:creator: By SU-HYUN LEE
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: An event at a shopping mall in Seoul in February for single people who didn't get chocolate on Valentine's Day.

item.title: Indonesians Cope With Infuriating Traffic and Inefficient Public Transit
item.description: With 9.9 million vehicles taking to the streets of Jakarta each workday, the daily commute can take a toll on stressed Indonesians.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Rony Zakaria for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Changing buses last week in Jakarta, Indonesia, where 9.9 million cars, motorcycles, trucks and other vehicles take to the streets each workday.

item.title: China Bans Milk Powder of 2 South Pacific Nations
item.description: Economists said a prolonged ban could create shortages in China, where nearly 90 percent of the milk powder imported last year originated in New Zealand.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Extends Closing of Some Diplomatic Posts
item.description: Nineteen diplomatic missions in the Middle East and North Africa will be shut down through at least Saturday because of continued fears of attacks by Al Qaeda and its allies.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Former Envoy to Syria Said to Be Choice for Cairo Post
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry recommended Robert S. Ford, who most recently served as a link to the Syrian opposition in the civil war, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Berlusconi Says Party to Back Italy’s Coalition
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister, said his center-right party would continue to support Italy’s coalition government, releasing some political tension that has built since his definitive conviction for tax fraud.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: London Journal: Bid to Honor Austen Is Not Universally Acknowledged
item.description: A push to get Jane Austen on Britain’s £10 note was met with online harassment, including threats of rape and death.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Mark J. Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, with a design for a £10 note featuring the author Jane Austen. The campaign for the bill was faced with a countercampaign of harassment.

item.title: A Rite of Passage, an Act of Defiance
item.description: The Palestinian stone throwers of Beit Ommar are a reminder of the tensions that animate relations between the Palestinians and the Israelis.

item.title: Iranian President Is Sworn In and Presents a New Cabinet of Familiar Faces
item.description: Many members of Hassan Rouhani’s cabinet, which must still be confirmed by Parliament, had served under a moderate former president.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Hassan Rouhani after he was sworn in in Tehran on Sunday.

item.title: Letter From Washington: Budget Fight Devolves to a Game of Chicken
item.description: As Republicans and Democrats brace for another showdown over the U.S. budget, they should take heed that waiting for the other side to blink is likely to have dire consequences for the country.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: In Germany, Union Culture Clashes With Amazon’s Labor Practices
item.description: Unions say the company has imported American-style business practices that stand at odds with European norms.
item.dc:creator: By NICK WINGFIELD and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Workers picketing an Amazon facility in Leipzig, Germany, demanding higher pay.

item.title: Victims to Again Face Gunman in Fort Hood Trial
item.description: Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, charged in the fatal Fort Hood shooting of 2009, will represent himself when his military trial begins on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By MANNY FERNANDEZ
item.media:description: Staff Sgt. Alonzo M. Lunsford Jr. was shot seven times by Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during an attack at the Fort Hood Army base in 2009. He will testify on the first day of Major Hasan’s military trial on Tuesday.

item.title: Syria Bans Use of Foreign Currencies for Business Deals
item.description: The ban, which carries fines and jail time for those who engage in such transactions without government approval, is an effort to prop up the Syrian pound, whose value has plummeted since 2011.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Indian University Cancels American’s Planned Talks
item.description: Amina Wadud, who has spoken widely on women’s role in Islam, said that lectures scheduled for the University of Madras were canceled amid security concerns.
item.dc:creator: By GAYATRI RANGACHARI SHAH

item.title: China Bans Milk Powder From New Zealand Over Botulism Fears
item.description: Imports from Australia were also affected by the decision, and economists said that a prolonged ban could produce a shortage of dairy products in China.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Australian Premier Calls Election for September 7
item.description: Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd called a general election for September 7, six weeks after he toppled former leader Julia Gillard in a party-room vote.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Restraint Urged for Egypt’s Security Services
item.description: Egypt’s interim vice president said on Saturday that force could be used only as a last resort to disperse demonstrations held by supporters of Mohamed Morsi.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and ASMAA AL ZOHAIRY

item.title: Mugabe Wins Again in Zimbabwe, Leaving Rival Greatly Weakened
item.description: President Robert Mugabe won 61 percent of the vote, said the Zimbabwe Election Commission, defeating Morgan Tsvangirai, who denounced the election, saying it had been rigged.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Robert G. Mugabe, center, defeated his main challenger, Morgan Tsvangirai, with 61 percent of the vote, the Zimbabwe Election Commission said Saturday.

item.title: Honduras to Militarize Main Prison After Clash
item.description: Honduran President Porfirio Lobo ordered the militarization after a gunfight at the country’s main prison left at least three gang members dead and 12 people injured, including three guards.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Day’s Toil in the Suicide Bombers’ Graveyard
item.description: Khwaja Naqib Ahmad lays claim to one of the toughest jobs in the Afghan capital — burying the unclaimed dead, including suicide bombers.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Christoph Bangert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khwaja Naqib Ahmad, 52, right, says he lives in fear that the Taliban will come to reclaim the bodies of their attackers. “Normally no one claims the bodies,” Mr. Ahmad said.

item.title: Thais Cast a Wide Net for Diverse Tourists
item.description: Thailand has a government-sponsored campaign aimed at gay and lesbian travelers, and is also marketing itself to Muslims.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Giulio Di Sturco for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: The Silom district of Bangkok, which is popular with gay men.
